passages.text: This material is neither intended to be distributed in Mainland China investors nor to provide securities investment consultancy services within the territory of Mainland China. This material or any portion hereof may not be reprinted, sold or redistributed without the written consent of J.P. Morgan.
Asia ex- Japan Equity Strategy (Rajiv Batra/Mixo Das/Wendy Liu/Khoi Vu, CFA), China, India, Indonesia, South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines

Our aggregate measure of investor positioning in Asia now sits around the 85th %ile (having gone as high as \(97^{\text{th}}\) %ile in July - Figure 1). While this would normally be considered a significant headwind, the global policy easing and China liquidity surge currently underway is providing a strong counter force. In this context, we believe the equity bull market will remain intact and any correction/consolidation will present a buying opportunity. However, it is important to manage risks where positioning is particularly crowded. Looking across LO, HF and Quant investors, we note the highest crowding in Taiwan Tech/Semis and Indo Financials, followed by China Growth stocks (semis, consumer and biotech). Alongside this, ongoing support from monetary policy should eventually warrant a widening of the leadership and outperformance of Cyclicals. We are upgrading the Materials sector to Ow in the AxJ region following our recent allocation changes in India (see report). Within the AxJ region, our pecking order is Korea > India > China > Taiwan > ASEAN. Our key OwS are: China Tech, Internet, Healthcare, Materials, select Financial/Industrials; India Financials, Consumer ex Auto, Materials, Real Estate, Hospitals, select power/defense; Korea Financials, Tech, Holdco; TSMC in Taiwan; and ASEAN Financials, Real Estate, Utilities, Healthcare, IT.

EM Money Trail (Rajiv Batra/Emy Shayo Cherman), Brazil, Chile, China, Colombia, Czech Republic, Egypt, Greece, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Kuwait, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, United Arab Emirates

EM equity funds squeezed in mild inflows (+\\$85mn) this week, following strong inflows last week (+\\$2.0bn). Within regional funds, GEMs posted marginal inflows (+\\$17mn), Asia ex- Japan saw a small sell- off (- \\$92mn, +\\$1.6bn last week), EMEA (+ \\$101mn) continued its strong run for the third week while LatAm saw net inflows of +\\$60mn. Total inflows continue to be led by ETFs, which saw small inflows this week (+\\$367mn) while non- ETFs sold- off (- \\$281mn). EM ex- China saw small subscriptions (+\\$30mn). YTD EM equity fund flows are - \\$5.4bn (ETFs: +\\$39.2bn, non- ETFs: - \\$44.6bn).
APAC Energy Transition (Alan Hon/Hannah L Lee)
Tightness and Tribulations: Ten Fresh Takes on Clean Energy Supply

The road to a clean energy future is long (and uncertain). While the energy transition remains an overarching theme, history has shown that renewable energy build- out at scale does not necessarily translate into returns at all points of the value chain. Industry cycles, technological advancement, and geopolitics all come into play. In this report, we give10 answers to questions relating to the transition on three main topics: 1) Which transition value chains are in supply tightness or emerging as important ones? 2) Where are geopolitical risks less well understood? 3) Which transition technologies will be the next game changers? JPM- covered stocks that emerge as our top picks include: Bannerman Energy (BMN), CATL- A, Hyundai Electric, Hyosung Heavy, ILU, LG Chem, LG Energy Solution, Orient Cables, Sieyuan and Tenaga.
Luxshare - A (Billy Feng) (002475 CH, OW, PT Rmb63.00), China

During the earnings call, management addressed: 1) strong revenue growth in auto and communication segments in 1H25, attributable to positive portfolio expansion, which is expected to boost growth continuously; 2) sustainable and resilient growth outlook, even in a complex macro situation, backed by its diversified business, globalized capacity, high- quality delivery and its superior capability of intelligent manufacture; and, 3) better- than- expected consolidation of newly acquired business (including Leoni and ODM business, both settled in July). We expect a better revenue mix (rising contribution from high- margin auto and communication segments) and project a \(26\%\) earnings CAGR in 2024- 27. We reiterate OW on Luxshare with an extended Jun- 26 PT of Rmb63.
Huaqin Technology - A (Cherry Liu / Billy Feng) (603296 CH, OW, PT Rmb115.00), China

Key takeaways from Huaqin's earnings call include: 1) strong earnings growth of \(46\%\) yoy in 1H25 was driven by accelerating Al server delivery and strong momentum in smartphone/PC/wearable areas; 2) GPM dropped sequentially in 2Q25, due to product mix change, but is expected to recover with a better mix; 3) management expects \(>Rmb40bn\) datacenter revenue in 2025 and further growth ahead, given continuous demand from CSPs and Huaqin's full- stack portfolio with share- gain potential; and 4) an unchanged target of a \(\sim 17\%\) revenue CAGR and stronger earnings growth with margin expansion in 2024- 30. We consider Huaqin's growth outlook to be intact, supported by strong momentum across its diversified layout; reiterate OW with a Jun- 26 PT of Rmb115.
LatAm Bottlers (Lucas Fegreira), Mexico, Chile
2H Liftoff Hindered by Bad Weather & Slow Consumer - Yet Mx Peers' Multiples More Than Discount It

We expect 2H25 values for LatAm Bottlers to improve and still bring high- single- digit to low- double- digit EBITDA growth in 2H for most peers despite a persistently challenging weather pattern in Mexico and Brazil and a still sluggish consumption environment in key regions. Moreover, we believe market expectations, especially for KOF but also AC, largely reflect what should best still sluggish 3Q. As we revise our estimates for the Mx Bottlers, we find valuation enticing having underperformed the Mx 51% by \(21\%\) / \(5\%\) pp (KOF/AC) respectively YTD and trading on avg at a \(15\%\) discount to the broader Mx Consumer peers, which are likely exposed to similar demand side risks but with a less resilient pricing power (here) while remaining with a superior 5yr EPS CAGR. In the case of Andina, we see limited room for further re- rating, trading at a \(10\%\) premium vs Mx Peers with similar EPS CAGR while it has slightly outperformed its local trading index (IPSA). Compared to consensus, our EBITDA estimates for this and next year for KOF are \(2 / 3\%\) ahead vs BBG consensus but mostly in line for AC and Andina.
Mexico Retail (Joseph Giordano/Froylan Mendez), Mexico
2H25 to Be Another Chapter of Underwhelming Results - Position for Savvy and Selective Consumer

Key consumption leading indicators do not show a clear picture of an inflection point into 2H25E beyond the seasonal recovery from lapping a tough comparable base from the three- electoral period in 1H25. Remittances, job creation and real wage mass continued to lose momentum into July while NITAD (here) reading was also underwhelming. With this in mind, we believe 2H25E will be another chapter of the tale of several Mexicos (here) depicting a more selective, savvy and price/promotion driven consumer with very distinct dynamics among consumer profiles and consumption occasions. Our top sector pick remains OW- rated (TBBB), benefiting from a format gaining consumer share and occupying market white spaces. Among traditional supermarkets, we prefer N- rated Chedraui, which after a rally YTD trades mostly in line with Walnex and is still expected to outperform the latter in 2H, with limited but welcomed gross margin expansion, despite the industry's lack of pricing power. For N- rated FEMSA, our mildest 2H recovery view is due to the convenience format needing stronger economic acceleration to pick up. Still, a potential increase in buyback activity could be a trigger for the stock in the absence of a pick up in SSS. Liverpool's 2H SSS is expected to decelerate, on top of what appears to be a negative contribution from Nordstrom results already in Liverpool's bottom line, while we maintain a \(30\%\) governance discount.
LPP (Elena Jouronova, CFA) (LPP PW, N, PT zl15,600.00), Poland

LPP shares had a solid run over the last several months on the back of stronger than expected clothing retail sales data for Poland and the management's more positive comments about the trading environment and pricing in 2Q25 (CFO's recent interview to PAP Biznes). We expect LPP to print 2Q25 results ahead of our initial expectations and up FY25 EBITDA/EBIT/Net profit forecasts by \(4\% /7\% /8\%\) , largely due to more resilient gross margin (favorable FX movement, less discounting in Sinsay where excess inventory was lost in a fire at a DC, stable competitive backdrop). That said, for us the focus in the upcoming results is on sales per store in the Sinsay format and opex dynamics as they would showcase the impact of LPP's ambitious growth strategy - a key pillar of the investment case, in our opinion. We believe that similarly to JMT (OW, covered by Borja Olcese) and DNP (N) which reported 2Q25 LFLs at the low end of the Street's expectations and in the case of DNP in particular missed on higher opex, we could see some profit- taking in LPP if sales and operating margins do not beat Consensus expectations. We continue to see risks to long- term forecasts skewed to the downside for the retailer and that the cost of Sinsay store growth (as well as cannibalization of the existing network) is not fully factored in by the Sell Side (we sit 12- 16% below Bloomberg consensus on 2027- 28 Net Profit). We reiterate our N rating, slightly adjust our Jan- 27 PT to PLN 15,600/sh and continue to prefer Pepco (OW).
I Ningbo Tuopu (Rebecca Wen) (601689 CH, Underweight, PT Rmb40.00), China
A reality check for robots business; expect consensus earnings cuts; downgrade to UW
Asia ex- Japan Equity Strategy (Rajiv Batra/Mixo Das/Wendy Liu/Khoi Vu, CFA), China, India, Indonesia, South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines
Liquidity floats all, but manage risks in crowded spaces

EM Money Trail (Rajiv Batra/Emy Shayo Cherman), Brazil, Chile, China, Colombia, Czech Republic, Egypt, Greece, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Kuwait, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, United Arab Emirates
Mild inflows in EM, strong July subscriptions in China
Brazil (Vinicius Moreira)
Demand- related core CPI moved back up in July
Egypt MPC: A rather short "wait- and- see" (Gholahan S Taiwo), Egypt
CBE resumes its easing cycle delivering a sharp 200bp cut
India: Impact of US tariffs to grow over time (Toshi Jain)
India: July IP surprises positively, but headwinds to build (Divyanit Sood), India
Korea: Better than expected IP, modest upside risk to 3Q (Seok Gil Park), South Korea
Korea: BoK to remain on easing cycle for now (Seok Gil Park), South Korea
Korea: Non- construction domestic demand recovered in July (Jooen Kim), South Korea
Mexico Focus: Labor market bending, not breaking (Steven Palacio), Mexico
Less dovish tone due to upside risk to rice prices; Maintain \(4.5\%\) terminal rate, but push out next two cuts
